text: Anna De Smith actress
playwright well um I was born in a um
all black hospital so that gives you a
sense already that there was still such
a thing as that uh and I suppose there
are in some places so the town was uh
for all intents and purposes a
segregated town
um my mother was in labor for 5
days um I'm not sure if I'd been in a
different hospital if she if she had
been in a different hospital we had been
a different hospital if there would have
been a different kind of situation but I
sort of came down the birth canal and
then turned back up so I always have the
feeling that maybe I saw something that
I decided uh just uh take a little bit
longer coming along
um and uh I went to an Elementary School
that was also uh all um at the time
colored children negro children and um a
lot happened by the time it was time to
go to Junior High and I went to a
predominantly Jewish Junior High um and
a predominantly white high school um but
uh that didn't wouldn't have happened
for example if I were 5 years
older and uh and I grew up in many ways
in a different Baltimore than my mother
and my father
um and I think that you know I think
one's past always comes and goes but now
in
2007 what I find myself often calling up
about
Baltimore um is that the people
that I grew up around were nice people
and so niceness has become uh very
important to me now and uh I find myself
thinking about that um sort of kindness
uh love of
children
um uh the importance of my church uh uh
kind of quest for fairness and Justice
um in the nation as a whole I think and
I think about that a lot and uh try um
on a daily basis to uh emulate some of
that behavior in in the way I go about
my
life well it was really a community that
I grew up in um you know uh in terms of
my the culture that was right around me
that is my the people who I would call
my friends and family for the most part
they were colored people
um and uh my mother and father had a big
effect on me my patern atal grandfather
my maternal grandmother had a big effect
on me there was a woman next door called
Miss Johnson who was actually very large
woman about maybe she weighed about 400
PBS she had a huge effect on me she was
a great Storyteller and I used to ask
her to tell me stories all the time and
when kids were out playing uh well we
didn't have stickball in the street but
our version of softball or baseball in
the back alley um I would most likely be
found talking to Miss Johnson asking her
to tell me often some of the same
stories over and over again and so I
think that my desire to hear a story
which came from when I was very young is
still with me now and had a huge
influence on Me on the minister of my
church and his wife uh had a big effect
on me and then um I think the the
tougher part uh had to do with um my
schooling in junior high uh because the
kidss in that school really stayed in
groups that had mostly to do with with
race and um and social class so for
example even among the Jewish kids it
was really clear to me that they had a
certain pecking order and the the um the
kids whose families had recently come
for example from Eastern Europe were um
segregated again away from those who
were more assimilated um
and that really bothered me and you know
when something bothers you you can on
the one hand turn it into something
which I've tried to do in my life but
there's another way in which the fact of
it the fact of it never goes away and
you sort of see those same themes in
your own life and and certainly we live
in a world that may not be segregated in
the way that parts of this country were
but we live in a very tribal country
world now where there seems to be uh
a there seems to be a almost un
unsurmountable challenge in terms of how
do we soften those borders and
boundaries well I can't remember not
being conscious of race I I guess I'd
have to have been
prelingual uh because even
though most of the people around me were
African-American
people um there was still a sense when
you went into other parts of Baltimore
that there were white people um or for
example my grandmother my maternal
grandmother took my brother and I to a
uh enrolled us in a camp when I was
eight and he was six and um everybody in
that camp was white um except for one
African-American girl my brother had had
blue eyes and blonde hair so people
didn't always know that he was uh uh
black and so um you know I was very
conscious in that camp of of not being
white and I was eight years old then so
I think it's something that in my
generation is pretty deeply ingrained I
don't think that my niece um who is uh
nine has the same experience that that I
don't I don't think she's conscious but
I don't think she's self-conscious in
the way that I was because the message
to us was that it was something that you
know wasn't necessarily that great um
and so you had to count on the people in
your family and your your church and the
people who were closer to you to try to
um make sense of
that well I didn't really become
involved in the theater until I was uh
in after I got out of college when I was
a younger woman um you know for example
um I I wanted to be a linguist and I
thought that maybe there was some sort
of a job that I could have ultimately
that would have to do with learning many
languages and uh and doing something
about these things we've been talking
about how people don't get on very well
and it's interesting that I wanted to
learn other languages and take that into
the world because I could have said well
you know I want to follow in the heels
of Mark Luther King and do something
about race relations in this country but
I really had a a desire
to be in the world and to try to do
something about tribalism and I thought
that one way to do that and I use
tribalism in you know quotations um
Discord between groups and I thought
that language was a part of that somehow
so I guess I I thought that being able
to talk to one another as sort of um I
don't know trivial as that sounds I
think I really believed in that
possibility as a young
woman and then uh when I got out of
college uh and when when I was in
college a lot of things happened in this
country that um left many of us in a
kind of a quandry as to as to what we
should do uh with ourselves and with the
country Martin Luther King was uh killed
when I was in in in college um and um so
I went away to California with the
notion that I would do something in
social change um but by the time I got
there which was the early 70s the
movement was really over uh people were
just uh beginning to assemble themselves
I think to become what became the
yuppies of of the 1980s so that was like
over no nobody was uh into questioning
things anymore there was a sense that
people were just trying to put things
back together um and in that period I
happened to go to an acting class pretty
much kind of
accidentally and um and I thought well
my goodness everyone's changing so I
thought this would be a great laboratory
in which to um study change with the the
expectation that I would then go ahead
and do something about social change but
once I got that bug the bug not so much
the bug of acting I have to say more the
bug of the study of it the bug of the
process of
creativity really U took me by storm and
changed my life and so in three years I
sort of really redirected my goals
completely
